conclusion: Initial setup of the parallel-plate capacitor with plates separated by distance d, constant voltage V, metal plate of thickness l, charged particle P stationary above the metal plate, and gravity g acting downward.
The particle P being stationary implies forces are balanced initially, and we need to find its acceleration after the metal plate is removed.
Metal plate affects the electric field within the capacitor, with the lower plate assumed at potential 0 and upper plate at potential V.
Electric field in region above metal plate is E1 = V/(d - l), and inside the metal plate, the electric field E2 = 0.
Particle P experiences electric field E1 in the region above the metal plate.
Forces on particle P are balanced: gravitational force mg downward and electric force qE1 upward (assuming q < 0).
After removing the metal plate, the capacitor reverts to standard parallel-plate with separation d.
Electric field without the metal plate is E = V/d.
Forces on particle P after removing the plate: gravitational force mg downward and electric force |q|V/d upward.
Substituting |q| gives electric force F_e = mg(d - l)/d upward.
Net force on particle is F_net = mg(d - l)/d - mg downward.
Net force simplifies to F_net = mgl/d downward.
Acceleration of particle is a = gl/d downward.
Acceleration direction is downward due to reduced electric field after removing the metal plate.
Alternative charge assumption q > 0 leads to unbalanced forces initially, confirming q < 0 is correct.
Final answer: acceleration of the particle after removing the metal plate is gl/d downward.
